title: 104_hr858
content:
The "Firefighters Pay Fairness Act of 1995" aims to improve pay equality, recruitment, and retention of Federal firefighters while encouraging career advancement and training opportunities. The "Firefighters Pay Fairness Act of 1995" includes provisions for computing pay based on annual rates for firefighters, with rules for deriving hourly, daily, and biweekly rates. The annual rate of basic pay for firefighters is determined based on applicable provisions of law, and any amount considered part of basic pay under specific chapters should not be excluded. To calculate an annual rate, multiply the biweekly rate by 26. This annual rate is considered for all purposes unless otherwise provided by law. The annual rate of basic pay for firefighters is determined based on specific provisions of law, excluding certain amounts. Overtime computation for firefighters is governed by section 5542(e). For non-firefighter employees, different rules apply. For employees who are not firefighters but are required to perform firefighting duties, their pay for such duties will be determined based on applicable provisions of law, with the option to choose the method resulting in a greater total amount. Rates are calculated to the nearest cent. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made for employees other than firefighters in the relevant section of the United States Code. For the purpose of this section, the term 'employee' includes individuals working in Executive agencies, the judicial branch, and specific offices, but excludes certain individuals. The term 'firefighter' in this section refers to an employee who performs firefighting duties, excluding those with a basic administrative workweek of more than 40 hours. The term 'firefighter' excludes employees with a basic administrative workweek of more than 40 hours. Amendments are made to Section 5504 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 4. OVERTIME.

Amendment to Section 5542 of title 5, United States Code, defines overtime for firefighters working over 106 hours in a biweekly pay period. No violation under Fair Labor Standards Act if requirements are met.

SEC. 5. MINIMUM PAY RATE UPON PROMOTION TO A SUPERVISORY POSITION; PAY RETENTION. Minimum Pay Rate Upon Promotion to a Supervisory Position is amended to include definitions for firefighter and required minimum rate for promotions. The total amount of basic and overtime pay for firefighters is calculated based on the Firefighters Pay Fairness Act of 1995, including promotions to supervisory positions in higher grades. The Firefighters Pay Fairness Act of 1995 ensures that firefighters promoted to higher grades receive basic pay at a rate not less than their required minimum rate. Regulations will be in place to address pay retention for firefighters promoted while receiving saved pay. Regulations will be in place to address pay retention for firefighters promoted while receiving saved pay. Additionally, a new provision is added for those subject to a reduction or termination of a rate of pay established under section 5504(c)(1). SEC. 6. TRAINING.

Section 4109 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for firefighter training and payment during training periods.

SEC. 7. TECHNICIAN BONUSES.

Chapter 45 of title 5, United States Code, introduces awards for firefighters with special skills and certifications. Sec. 4531 defines 'firefighter' and 'firefighting duties'. Sec. 4532 allows agencies to award up to 5% of basic pay to firefighters or employees who perform firefighting duties and have special skills or certifications related to firefighting. Under this section, awards shall be paid according to agency regulations or collective bargaining agreements. The regulations or agreements must include procedures for verifying special skills, criteria for determining award amounts, and other necessary provisions. "Subchapter IV - Awards to firefighters for special skills and certifications includes definitions and award authority. Effective date, transition provisions, and reporting requirement are also specified in the section." The Act will take effect on October 1, 1995, with transition provisions for payment adjustments based on service performed in fiscal years 1996 and 1997. The Office of Personnel Management must report to Congress by June 1, 1995, on plans for implementing transition provisions and funding increases in pay resulting from the Act. Additionally, the need for regulatory or legislative modifications in the administration of retirement benefits for firefighters separating from service during fiscal years 1996 through 2002 should be assessed.
